math-encyclopedia/algebra/linear-algebra.description:
#Linear_Algebra Definition:
A vector space over a field is a non-empty set together with a binary operation and a binary function that satisfy eight axioms. The elements of are called vectorsvectors and the elements of are called scalars
The binary operation, called vector addition or simply addition assigns to any two vectors and in a third vector in which is commonly written as and is called the sum of these two vectors.
The binary function, called scalar multiplication assigns to any scalar in and any vector in another vector in which is denoted To have a vector space, the eight following axioms must be satisfied for every and

Show that and have the same homology groups and fundamental groups but a different homotopy type. Rotman Exercise 9.46proof:By Reduced Homology of Wedge SumReduced Homology of Wedge Sum we have that And by Kunneth FormulaKunneth Formula we have Thus by Sandwiched Zeros of Exact SequenceSandwiched Zeros of Exact Sequence we have In order for to be non-trivial, both terms must be non-trivial (in this case since they are spheres), thus we get Thus the four cases are (0,0), (1,0), (0,2), (1,2) and we get
By Fundamental Group of Products is Product of Fundamental GroupsFundamental Group of Products is Product of Fundamental Groups we have With the second to last isomorphism coming from Sn Fundamental GroupSn Fundamental Group (coming from n-1 connectedness of Snn-1 connectedness of Sn)
Then by Seifert-Van KampenSeifert-Van Kampen we have again by n-1 connectedness of Snn-1 connectedness of Sn.Suppose for purpose of contradiction that they are homotopy equivalent. Then the universal cover of looks like the real number line with the higher spheres wedged at each integer
which is homotopy equivalent to On the other hand, the universal cover of is equivalent to which is homotopy equivalent to which has trivial homology on dimension three and thus can't be homotopy equivalent to . Similarly, because it covers the space and is simply connected?
Then by Homotopy Equivalent Spaces Have Homotopy Equivalent Universal CoversHomotopy Equivalent Spaces Have Homotopy Equivalent Universal Covers, since the universal covers are not homotopy equivalent, neither are the spaces.

math-encyclopedia/latex/latex-suite-inst.title: Latex Suite Instructions
math-encyclopedia/latex/latex-suite-inst.description:
r: This indicates that the snippet's trigger should be treated as a regular expression. Regular expressions allow for more complex pattern matching, enabling you to define triggers that recognize various inputs rather than a fixed string.
m: This denotes Math mode. When m is included in the options, the snippet will only be activated when you are inside a LaTeX math block (e.g., between $ or $$ delimiters).
A: This stands for Auto-expansion. If A is present, the snippet will expand automatically as soon as the trigger text is typed. If A is omitted, you'll need to press Tab (or the assigned expansion key) after typing the trigger to activate the snippet.

Examples: Circle: the set of points at a constant distance (the radius) from a fixed point (the center) Parabola: the set of points equidistant from a fixed point (the focus) and a line (the directrix)

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
